  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features birds perched on bamboo-like branches. The branches extend from the bottom of the kain
 alongside small flowering plant forms. Small twigs
 with leaves and flowers attached
 are interspersed on the top half of the kain.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan birds (motifs) foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Batik

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  sgcool_label_text: Red-breasted birds perched on branches decorate this blue kain panjang.  Filler motifs and alternating colours add texture and depth to the depiction of branches and leaves.  Twigs
 with attached leaves and flowers
 are depicted on the upper half the kain panjang.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features birds perched on bamboo-like branches. The branches extend from the bottom of the kain, alongside small flowering plant forms. Small twigs, with leaves and flowers attached, are interspersed on the top half of the kain.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Batik
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Red-breasted birds perched on branches decorate this blue kain panjang.  Filler motifs and alternating colours add texture and depth to the depiction of branches and leaves.  Twigs, with attached leaves and flowers, are depicted on the upper half the kain panjang.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.
